title: Your First Search
description: Write and run your first Splunk searches. Learn basic search syntax, keywords, and how to read results.
objectives: Use index and sourcetype to find the right data
Combine search terms with AND, OR, and NOT

sections.title: The Simplest Search
sections.body: Let's start with the simplest possible search—just a keyword.
sections.explanation:
This searches all data for events containing the word "error". Simple, but:

  • It searches everything (slow)
  • It might return millions of results
  • Results come from all different data sources

This works, but let's make it better.

sections.title: Specifying an Index
sections.body: Always start your searches by specifying which index to search. This is faster and more focused.

example.description: Search for 'error' in a specific index

sections.explanation:
index=_internal tells Splunk to only search Splunk's internal logs. Now:

  • Search is faster (only one index)
  • Results are relevant (all from same source)
  • You know exactly what you're looking at

Best Practice: Always include index= at the start of your searches.

sections.title: Adding More Keywords
sections.body: You can include multiple keywords. By default, they're combined with AND—all must be present.

example.description: Search for events with both 'error' and 'connection'

sections.explanation: This finds events that contain both "error" AND "connection". The keywords can appear anywhere in the event, in any order.

sections.title: Exact Phrases
sections.body: Use quotes for exact phrases that must appear together.
sections.explanation:
Without quotes, connection refused finds events with both words anywhere.

With quotes, "connection refused" finds only events with that exact phrase.

sections.title: Boolean Operators: OR
sections.body: Use OR to find events with either term (or both).

example.description: Search for events with error OR warning

sections.explanation:
This returns events containing "error", events containing "warning", and events containing both.

Note: OR must be uppercase. Lowercase "or" is treated as a search keyword.

sections.title: Boolean Operators: NOT
sections.body: Use NOT to exclude events containing a term.

example.description: Search for errors that aren't about memory

sections.explanation:
This finds events with "error" that do NOT contain "memory". Useful for filtering out noise.

Note: NOT must be uppercase.

sections.title: Combining Boolean Operators

example.spl: index=_internal (error OR warning) NOT (debug OR info)

sections.explanation:
This finds events with "error" or "warning" but excludes those that also have "debug" or "info".

Parentheses work like in math—they group operations together.

sections.title: Searching Specific Fields
sections.body: Instead of searching everywhere, search specific fields using field=value.

example.description: Search for events from a specific host

sections.explanation: This only returns events where the host field equals "myserver". Much more precise than just searching for the hostname as a keyword.

sections.title: Wildcards
sections.body: Use * as a wildcard to match partial values.
sections.explanation:
This matches web01, web02, webserver, etc.—anything starting with "web".

Wildcards can appear anywhere: *server* matches "webserver", "dbserver", "server01", etc.

example.description: Search for events with status code 400 or higher

sections.title: A Complete Search Example
sections.body: Let's put it all together with a realistic security search.
sections.explanation:
This search:

  1. Looks in the _internal index
  2. Filters to splunkd sourcetype (Splunk's main daemon logs)
  3. Finds ERROR level events
  4. Contains "authentication" or "login"
  5. Excludes events mentioning "success"

Each piece narrows down the results to exactly what you need.

sections.title: Reading Your Results
sections.body:
After running a search, understand what you're seeing.

Results Panel

  • Event count: Shows at top ("X events")
  • Time distribution: Timeline shows when events occurred
  • Event list: Individual events with timestamp and raw text

Each Event Shows

  • Timestamp: When the event occurred
  • Raw event: The original log text
  • Field values: Click the arrow to expand and see extracted fields

Using Results

  • Click a value in an event to add it to your search
  • Expand events to see all extracted fields
  • Use the timeline to zoom into specific time ranges

sections.title: Practice Exercises
sections.body:
Try these searches to practice basic syntax.

Exercise 1: Simple Keyword

Search for any events containing "error" in the _internal index with Last 15 minutes selected.

exercises.title: Exercise 2: Boolean OR
exercises.prompt: Find events with either 'error' OR 'warn' in _internal

exercises.title: Exercise 3: Exclusion
exercises.prompt: Find errors but exclude anything about 'scheduler'

exercises.title: Exercise 5: Wildcard
exercises.prompt: Find events from any sourcetype starting with 'splunk'

content.summary:
Key Takeaways

  • Always start with index= to specify where to search
  • Keywords search anywhere in events; field=value searches specific fields
  • Use quotes for exact phrases: "connection refused"
  • Boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT) combine conditions—must be uppercase
  • Use parentheses to group complex logic
  • Wildcards (*) match partial values
  • Comparison operators (>, <, =, !=) work with numeric fields
